The TARDBP (TAR DNA-binding protein) gene encodes TDP-43, a crucial RNA-binding protein involved in RNA processing and stress granule dynamics. Mutations in TARDBP are strongly associated with frontotemporal lobar degeneration (FTLD) and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). In particular, TARDBP mutations lead to the mislocalization and aggregation of TDP-43, contributing to neuronal dysfunction and degeneration. This pathology is a hallmark of FTLD with TDP-43 proteinopathy and is also observed in ALS. The disruption of TDP-43 in the pathway involving complex I subunits suggests a link between mitochondrial dysfunction and neurodegeneration. These mutations impair RNA metabolism and protein homeostasis, leading to progressive neuronal loss. The biological effect of the TARDBP allele is therefore a key contributor to TDP-43-related neurodegenerative diseases.

\boxed{Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis}

The TARDBP gene encodes TDP-43, a protein involved in RNA processing and stress granule dynamics. Mutations in TARDBP are associated with the mislocalization and aggregation of TDP-43, leading to neuronal damage. This pathology is a hallmark of several neurodegenerative diseases. Specifically, TARDBP mutations are a major genetic cause of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), a fatal neurological disorder characterized by the progressive degeneration of motor neurons. TDP-43 proteinopathy is also observed in frontotemporal lobar degeneration (FTLD), including frontal cortex degeneration and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis with frontotemporal features (ALS-FTLD). \boxed{Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis}

The VHL allele, as part of the VHL-RBX1-ELOC-ELOB-CUL2 complex, plays a critical role in the ubiquitin ligase pathway that targets HIF1A for degradation under normoxic conditions. Inactivation of VHL disrupts this process, leading to stabilization of HIF1A. This results in the activation of HIF1A-ARNT transcriptional activity, driving the expression of genes such as VEGFA, PDGFB, and TGFB, which promote angiogenesis, cell survival, and fibrosis. This pathway is central to hypoxia response and tumor progression. Mutations in VHL are the primary cause of von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease, a hereditary disorder characterized by the formation of benign and malignant tumors in multiple organs, including the kidneys, adrenal glands, and central nervous system. The accumulation of HIF1A in VHL-deficient cells drives the pathogenesis of renal cell carcinoma, hemangioblastomas, and other VHL-associated neoplasms. \boxed{Von Hippel-Lindau disease}

The CDKN2A allele plays a critical role in the regulation of the p53 and RB1 pathways. CDKN2A encodes p16INK4a, which inhibits CDK4/6, preventing the phosphorylation of RB1. This keeps E2F transcription factors in check, limiting cell cycle progression. When CDKN2A is mutated or deleted, this inhibition is lost, leading to unchecked cell proliferation. This contributes to the dysregulation of cell cycle control, a hallmark of cancer. Specifically, CDKN2A alterations are strongly associated with melanoma and pancreatic cancer. Mutations in CDKN2A are also linked to Li-Fraumeni syndrome, a hereditary disorder characterized by a high risk of multiple cancers. Thus, the biological effect of CDKN2A loss is the promotion of uncontrolled cell growth, contributing to cancer development.

\boxed{Melanoma}

The KCNC3 gene encodes a voltage-gated potassium channel subunit (Kv3.3) that plays a critical role in neuronal excitability by regulating action potential repolarization. Mutations in KCNC3 have been associated with disorders characterized by abnormal electrical activity in the nervous system. Specifically, loss-of-function mutations in KCNC3 contribute to **epilepsy**, particularly **developmental and progressive epilepsies**. These mutations disrupt normal potassium channel function, leading to hyperexcitability of neurons and increased susceptibility to seizures. Additionally, KCNC3 mutations have been linked to **neurodevelopmental disorders** and **intellectual disability** in some cases. The altered ion homeostasis caused by these mutations impairs neuronal function, leading to the clinical manifestations observed in affected individuals. \boxed{Epilepsy}

This pathway describes the intracellular signaling cascade initiated by the amyloid beta precursor protein (APP), leading to the production of amyloid-beta, activation of muscarinic acetylcholine receptors (mAChRs), and subsequent stimulation of GNAQ and PLCB, resulting in IP3 production. IP3 triggers the release of calcium from the endoplasmic reticulum, which is then taken up by mitochondria via MCU. Excess mitochondrial calcium can lead to mitochondrial permeability transition pore (MPTP) opening, causing the release of cytochrome c (CYCS), a key initiator of apoptosis. This pathway is central to neurodegeneration, particularly in Alzheimer's disease, where APP processing leads to amyloid-beta accumulation, mitochondrial dysfunction, and neuronal death. The involvement of multiple genes in this pathway underscores its role in disease progression. \boxed{Alzheimer's disease}

Mutations in PRKN lead to impaired mitochondrial quality control, resulting in the accumulation of dysfunctional mitochondria. This dysfunction is linked to neurodegeneration. The biological effect of this PRKN allele is therefore a key contributor to Parkinson's disease.

The APRT (adenine phosphoribosyltransferase) gene encodes an enzyme involved in the salvage pathway of purine metabolism. This enzyme catalyzes the conversion of adenine to inosine monophosphate (IMP). Mutations in the APRT gene lead to reduced enzymatic activity, resulting in the accumulation of adenine and its metabolites, such as 2,6-diamino-4-hydroxypteridine (2,6-DAP), which is neurotoxic. This accumulation causes progressive neurological deterioration. The most well-documented disease associated with APRT deficiency is Lesch–Nyhan syndrome, a rare X-linked recessive disorder characterized by neurological symptoms, self-harming behaviors, and intellectual disability. The disorder arises from mutations in the APRT gene, leading to impaired purine metabolism and neurotoxic accumulation of metabolites. \boxed{Lesch–Nyhan syndrome}

Mutations in APRT can lead to reduced activity of the enzyme, resulting in the accumulation of adenine and its metabolites, such as 2,6-diaminopurines, which are toxic. This accumulation leads to the deposition of urate crystals in tissues, particularly in the kidneys, causing a progressive disorder known as Lesch-Nyhan syndrome. This X-linked recessive disorder is characterized by neurological abnormalities, self-mutilating behavior, and severe gout-like symptoms due to hyperuricemia. Therefore, the biological effect of a pathological APRT allele is the development of Lesch-Nyhan syndrome.

\boxed{Lesch-Nyhan syndrome}

The BRAF pathway is a critical signaling cascade involved in cell proliferation, survival, and differentiation. The BRAF gene encodes a serine/threonine kinase that activates the mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) cascade by phosphorylating MEK, which in turn activates ERK. Mutations in BRAF, particularly the V600E activating mutation, lead to constitutive activation of this pathway, driving uncontrolled cell growth. This dysregulation is commonly observed in melanoma, where BRAF mutations are found in approximately 50% of cases. The persistent activation of ERK promotes tumor progression, angiogenesis, and resistance to apoptosis. Additionally, BRAF mutations have been implicated in other cancers, including colorectal, lung, and thyroid cancers. However, the most well-characterized and prevalent disease associated with BRAF mutations is \boxed{Melanoma}.

The PSAP (prosaposin) gene encodes a precursor protein essential for the proper folding and activity of four sphingolipid-degrading enzymes: GBA, GBA2, GALC, and ARSA. Mutations in PSAP lead to reduced levels of these enzymes, causing accumulation of sphingolipids in lysosomes. This results in a rare lysosomal storage disorder known as metachromatic leukodystrophy (MLD). MLD is characterized by progressive demyelination of the central and peripheral nervous system, leading to severe neurological deficits. PSAP mutations are the second most common cause of MLD, with the most common form being late-onset MLD. The disease is typically diagnosed in childhood and is often fatal without intervention. The pathway's involvement highlights the critical role of PSAP in maintaining lysosomal enzyme stability and function. 

\boxed{Metachromatic Leukodystrophy}

The PINK1 pathway is central to mitochondrial quality control and apoptosis. PINK1, a mitokine, stabilizes when mitochondria are damaged, leading to the recruitment and activation of PRKN (parkin), an E3 ubiquitin ligase. This initiates the ubiquitination and degradation of damaged mitochondria via autophagy. PINK1 also promotes the translocation of BAX to the mitochondrial outer membrane, triggering the release of cytochrome c (CYCS). Cytochrome c then binds to APAF1, forming the apoptosome, which activates CASP9 and subsequently CASP3, leading to apoptosis. Mutations in PINK1 disrupt this process, leading to impaired mitophagy and neuronal death. This contributes to Parkinson's disease, characterized by the degeneration of dopaminergic neurons. \boxed{Parkinson's disease}

The NAGS gene encodes N-acetylglutamate synthase, an enzyme critical for the urea cycle. This enzyme catalyzes the formation of N-acetylglutamate, a key activator of carbamoyl-phosphate synthetase I (CPS1), which initiates the urea cycle. Mutations in NAGS lead to reduced CPS1 activity, impairing ammonia detoxification. This results in hyperammonemia, a condition characterized by elevated blood ammonia levels. The most common disorder associated with NAGS mutations is **N-acetylglutamate synthase deficiency**, a rare autosomal recessive disorder. This condition leads to neurological symptoms, including seizures, developmental delays, and intellectual disability. The pathway defect disrupts urea synthesis, leading to toxic ammonia accumulation, particularly in the brain. The disease is often diagnosed in infancy and is associated with a high risk of mortality if untreated. \boxed{N-acetylglutamate synthase deficiency}

The thyroid peroxidase (TPO) enzyme plays a critical role in thyroid hormone synthesis by catalyzing the organification of iodide onto tyrosine residues in thyroglobulin, forming monoiodotyrosine (MIT) and diiodotyrosine (DIT). These are then coupled to form triiodothyronine (T3) and thyroxine (T4). Mutations in the TPO gene impair this process, leading to reduced hormone production. This dysfunction contributes to autoimmune thyroid disease, specifically **Hashimoto's thyroiditis**, an inflammatory condition where the immune system attacks the thyroid gland. The resulting hypothyroidism is a hallmark of this disease. TPO antibodies are also commonly found in patients with Hashimoto's thyroiditis, further linking TPO dysfunction to the pathogenesis of the disease. \boxed{Hashimoto's thyroiditis}

The NAGS gene encodes N-acetylglutamate synthase, an enzyme critical for the urea cycle. This enzyme catalyzes the formation of N-acetylglutamate from acetyl-CoA and glutamine, which is a key activator of CPS1 (carbamoyl-phosphate synthase 1), the first enzyme in the urea cycle. Mutations in NAGS can lead to reduced activity of CPS1, causing a deficiency in the urea cycle. This results in the accumulation of ammonia, leading to hyperammonemia. The most well-documented disorder associated with NAGS mutations is **N-acetylglutamate synthase deficiency**, a rare autosomal recessive disorder. It is characterized by neurological symptoms due to elevated ammonia levels, including seizures, developmental delay, and intellectual disability. The disease is part of the broader urea cycle disorders. \boxed{N-acetylglutamate synthase deficiency}
